author: andschwa
body:
These tests are currently failing on Linux / OS X, and are regressions because the tests are not run under CI.

The *nix implementations of Get/Set ExecutionPolicy behave as defined in their Pester tests; however, e7f07688f caused a regression by removing these cmdlets' declarations entirely.

```
Describing ExecutionPolicy
   Context Check Get-ExecutionPolicy behavior
    [-] Should unrestricted when not on Windows 93ms
      The term 'Get-ExecutionPolicy' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable progra
m. Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
      at line: 5 in /home/andrew/src/PowerShell/test/powershell/Modules/Microsoft.PowerShell.Security/ExecutionPolicy.Tes
ts.ps1
    [!] Should return Microsoft.Powershell.ExecutionPolicy PSObject on Windows 17ms
   Context Check Set-ExecutionPolicy behavior
    [-] Should throw PlatformNotSupported when not on Windows 94ms
      Expected: the expression to throw an exception with message {Operation is not supported on this platform.}, an exce
ption was raised, message was {The term 'Set-ExecutionPolicy' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script
 file, or operable program. Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct an
d try again.}
          from /home/andrew/src/PowerShell/test/powershell/Modules/Microsoft.PowerShell.Security/ExecutionPolicy.Tests.ps
1:15 char:15
          +             { Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted } | Should Throw "Oper ...
          +               ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
      at line: 15 in /home/andrew/src/PowerShell/test/powershell/Modules/Microsoft.PowerShell.Security/ExecutionPolicy.Te
sts.ps1
      15:             { Set-ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted } | Should Throw "Operation is not supported on this platform."
    [!] Should succeed on Windows 9ms
```

/cc @vors @JamesWTruher

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Oof this gets more serious. Because PowerShell inherits `PSMODULEPATH` this bug does not manifest if you run PowerShell from PowerShell (like CI does via Start-PSPester). This only reproduces if you run it directly with a clean environment, in which case the modules manifests from the build are used, and the cmdlets are missing.

title: ExecutionPolicy test failures
